    on entend parfois ces jours-ci que Google n' a pas su se réinventer,... Indépendamment de l' essor technologique de son infrastructure qui est même pratiquement impossible a décrire, cette animation décrit assez bien le travail réalisé pour le garder pendant 25 ans au niveau de ce que nous attendons de lui.

    Yonca Dervisoglu
    5d

    Google is 25 years old! Thinking back to when I was a child, my family moved from Istanbul, Turkey to Berkeley, California, where my dad was a professor. Being in an environment like that was a dream come true. I was surrounded by libraries, brilliant professors and inquisitive students, and it really drove home how much access to information matters. So years later, when I first saw the Internet - wow. I saw a technology that I knew could change the world, providing equal access to information for people everywhere - not just those lucky enough to be in Silicon Valley. That’s why I joined the technology industry two decades ago, and Google shortly after. It was in the middle of the dot com bust, when many people were running the other way! But it didn’t matter. I believed in the power of the Internet - yes for businesses, but even more than that, as a force for good. After more than seventeen years at Google, I’ve been fortunate to have more memorable moments than I can count (certainly more than 25!) When I think back to the values that made us successful in the early days - scrappiness, thinking big, focusing relentlessly on users and customers - those are the ones that still define us. My team might be a little larger now, but I see countless examples every day, across every aspect of the business, that make me proud and grateful to work here. I’ve also been reminded over and over again that it’s the people who make an experience special. I’ve been so lucky to be surrounded by some of the best people in the world for so long. My boss, Lorraine, who has inspired, challenged and supported me every step of the way. Matt, my partner in every aspect of the business, who's always pushing me to think bigger. My colleagues and friends on the leadership team: Alison, Marie, Simon, Danielle, Nicholas, Adrienne, Marvin, Lisa, Robert, Tara, Jeff, Sarah, and Andy. My wonderful EMEA leaders: Rainer, Eileen, Kristell, Torsten, and Phil. And of course, our entire EMEA Marketing team, who inspire me and keep me going every single day. The best part of the job is working with all of you. One last thought. The most common question I get from Nooglers (aka “New Googlers”) is whether they missed the wave and joined too late. I tell them that these are still the very earliest days. Like I had hoped, the Internet has brought access and opportunity to billions around the world. But at Google, we are really just scratching the surface in terms of what we can do. Right now, we’re investing heavily in new emerging technologies like AI and quantum computing. We’re launching new products that reimagine how we can help people and help businesses grow.  And our team is full of proactive, collaborative and mission-driven individuals who want to make an impact. So I tell them they should be more excited than ever. I most definitely am. Happy 25th, Google. And Search On, everyone.

    6

  • Julien Blanchez

    Digital Sovereignty Solution Lead at Google

    6d

    To all of us who can relate to these days in the 90 -00's packing some sort of hardware in cages or boxes, dreaming of changing the world. Well, some succeeded and 'all together' the world changed ;)

    Urs Hölzle

    Google Fellow

    1w

    A trip down memory lane...exactly 25 years ago Google signed its first datacenter contract.  Let's walk through the lease in a thread. First, the copy you see here was sent by a "fax machine" which was something people used back then. The data center provider was Exodus, a now-defunct company that was a leading provider at the time and had a market cap of tens of billions of dollars at the height of the dotcom bubble.  The facility was located at 2251 Lawson Lane in Santa Clara (since torn down). The first item on the order is a VDC (Virtual Data Center) measuring 7x4 feet (2.1x1.2m). You could barely lay down a mattress in this space. Imagine a "cage" with a mesh wire fence and a door, and inside there was a set of shelves (kinda like bookshelves) with PCs on it. A1 through a24 were the main machines to build and serve the index and c1 through c4 were the crawl machines. (There were no b machines.) I say "machine" not "server" because they were whitebox office PC enclosures with external disks attached. Note the handwritten addition at the bottom, requesting 3 20A power circuits.  That's 3*16A usable @ 110V, or about 5kW, so each machine drew less than 180W. Back then, data centers were priced by the sqft even though the actual cost of providing data center space is almost exclusively proportional to power, so by asking for extra power Larry got a better deal. Still, at $4000/month this was the world's most expensive mattress-sized space. Until you look at the cost of bandwidth: $1200/month for a single Mbps. We had two lines, one for web crawling and one for serving. It took until the Spring of 1999 for http://google.com to break through the 2Mbps usage commit! I first set foot in the Google data center four months later on Feb 1st, 1999. Well, not really, you couldn’t really “set foot” in that small a space.  Larry had led me there for a tour (I wasn’t an employee yet) and it was my first time in any data center. A short while afterwards we got an additional cage (maybe 3x larger) for 84 servers across 4 racks (assembled by a local shop called King Star Computer, IIRC). Finally, in June we got a still very crammed cage for 2400 of the infamous "cork board" servers, one of which you can see at the Computer History Museum, Natural History Museum, and a few more. It had some adventurous features but if you have just 2-3 weeks to design a very high density rack on the cheap, and haven't ever done it before, that's what you get :-) But it all started with 28 sqft of space and a few PCs.

    15

  • Julien Blanchez

    I didn't know Bram and I had to lookup VIM. But he made me think of the multitude of builders in the shadow, who dedicate their lives to building the tools and infrastructure that perpetuate evolution beyond what we can imagine is possible.

    Urs Hölzle

    Google Fellow

    1mo

    R.I.P. Bram Moolenaar (https://lnkd.in/exTCxUC9), creator of the Vim editor and 15-year Googler. His family wrote "It is with a heavy heart that we have to inform you that Bram Moolenaar passed away on 3 August 2023. Bram was suffering from a medical condition that progressed quickly over the last few weeks. Bram dedicated a large part of his life to VIM and he was very proud of the VIM community that you are all part of." OSS simply would not exist without people like Bram. He stood out for the broad impact his work had on millions of developers. As we remember Bram, let's also be thankful for the developers before and after him who have made open source possible through their own contributions.

    Bram Moolenaar - Wikipedia

    en.wikipedia.org

    Et voila , San Francisco grants driverless permit to taxi service. It took a bit longer than initially expected. Of course it will also take a while before such things happen in Europe ( don't they all :) ) but I'm really happy to know that many are thinking seriously about this now.

    Waymo

    173,772 followers

    1mo

    We’ve been waiting for this moment and now we can share it with you: Today, we received our paid driverless permit from the CPUC! In the coming weeks, we’ll begin charging fares for rider-only trips and welcoming new riders into Waymo One in San Francisco. We know demand will be high as more riders get access to ride across the city, but we want to ensure we provide a reliable service for everyone so we’ll be welcoming new riders incrementally. Thanks to everyone who shared their ongoing support—from riders to community advocates, and SF residents. https://lnkd.in/gzxS7gM3

    Oviva , European digital health company, can now also extend on public cloud in Germany through a Sovereign Cloud deployment with T-Systems.

    Google Cloud

    2,053,502 followers

    2mo

    Oviva, a digital health company, provides app-guided therapy to improve the eating and lifestyle habits of people with obesity. To enable its patients easier access to care and accelerate its growth through a more stable, scalable, and secure platform for its services, Oviva moved to the T-Systems International Sovereign Cloud, Powered by Google Cloud. Read the case study to find out more 👇

    Oviva Case Study | Google Cloud

    cloud.google.com
